document_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Aspergillus and Penicillium Species Isolated from the International Space Station and Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule
summary_full: This study reports the draft whole-genome sequences (WGS) of 30 fungal strains belonging to the Aspergillus and Penicillium genera, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and a crew resupply vehicle (CRV). The WGS were generated using Illumina sequencing and assembled with SPAdes. Species identification was performed using ITS, calmodulin, and Î²-tubulin sequences. The generated WGS will enable detailed genomic characterization, facilitating the exploration of potential applications in space and biotechnological industries. The study also highlights the importance of these fungi as models for investigating the effects of microgravity and irradiation on adaptation and evolution.
key_findings: Draft whole-genome sequences (WGS) were successfully assembled for 30 fungal strains (Aspergillus and Penicillium) isolated from the ISS and CRV.
The WGS provide a foundation for detailed genomic characterization of these space-isolated fungi.

The study identified multiple species within the Aspergillus and Penicillium genera, including Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus welwitschiae, Aspergillus unguis, and various Penicillium species such as P. camemberti, P. chrysogenum, P. dipodomyicola, P. griseoroseum, and P. polonicum.
The data is publicly available in GenBank and the NASA GeneLab system for further research.
future_research_fields: Investigating the impact of microgravity and irradiation on fungal adaptation and evolution.
Exploring potential biotechnological applications of these space-isolated fungi, such as antibiotic production, bioremediation, or production of valuable compounds.
Comparative genomic analyses between ISS-isolated strains and their terrestrial counterparts.
Further characterization of secondary metabolite production and other metabolic pathways.

conclusions: The generation of draft whole-genome sequences for Aspergillus and Penicillium species isolated from the ISS and CRV is a significant step towards understanding their genomic characteristics. These sequences will be invaluable for future research into their adaptation to the space environment and their potential applications in biotechnology.
impact_statement: This study provides essential genomic data for fungi found in the unique environment of the International Space Station, paving the way for novel biotechnological applications and insights into microbial adaptation in space.
